sources.title: A Stranger In Town
sources.description: A Supreme Court Justice goes fishing in a small town and gets involved with a country lawyer in cleaning up the corrupt town leaders.

sources.title: A Stranger in Town
sources.description: Visiting a small town in order to hunt ducks, supreme court judge Frank Morgan (the Wizard of Oz) discovers abuse of power by public servants.

sources.title: A Stranger in Town (1943) | Colorized Public Domain Comedy Drama with Frank Morgan & Richard Carlson
sources.description:
A Stranger in Town (1943) is a patriotic comedy-drama directed by Roy Rowland and released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer during World War II. The film stars Frank Morgan, Richard Carlson, and Jean Rogers in a charming and witty story about small-town corruption, civic duty, and democracy in action. Lighthearted yet meaningful, the film combines humor, romance, and social commentary, reflecting the American spirit of its wartime era.

This restored and colorized edition brings a vivid new look to the classic, making it accessible for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and worldwide.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Supreme Court Justice John Josephus Grant (Frank Morgan), who decides to take a fishing vacation in a small town incognito. Instead of peace and quiet, he discovers a community plagued by petty corruption, political bosses, and a rigged mayoral election.

Young lawyer Bill Adams (Richard Carlson) is running for mayor on a reform ticket but faces intimidation and dirty tricks from entrenched interests led by Judge Austin Harkley (Porter Hall). Grant, amused yet disturbed, secretly helps Bill by offering sharp legal advice, guiding him in courtroom battles, and inspiring him to stand up for the people.

Meanwhile, romance blossoms between Bill and lawyer Lucy Gilbert (Jean Rogers). With humor, courtroom wit, and a touch of patriotic messaging, the film builds toward a hopeful conclusion where integrity and democracy prevail. In the final scene, Grant quietly returns to Washington, satisfied that justice â€” in every sense â€” has been served.

Film Significance:
A Stranger in Town is notable for blending patriotic wartime messaging with a light comic touch. Released in 1943, it reflected American ideals of fairness, civic responsibility, and the fight against corruption at a time when the country was engaged in global conflict.

Frank Morgan, best remembered as the Wizard in The Wizard of Oz (1939), shines here in one of his best later roles, delivering both humor and gravitas. The filmâ€™s courtroom speeches and democratic themes connected strongly with audiences of the 1940s, while today it offers insight into how Hollywood supported wartime morale with entertaining yet thoughtful films.

metadata.Plot: The Charlestown neighborhood of Boston is renowned for churning out a high number of armed robbers, generation after generation. These robbers never leave their Charlestown life on their own volition, the neighborhood where there is an unwritten code to protect that lifestyle. Such robbers include friends Doug MacRay, James Coughlin, Albert 'Gloansy' Magloan and Desmond Elden. Doug and James in particular treat each other like family, as the Coughlins have realistically been as such to Doug since Doug's mother ran off and Doug's father, Stephen MacRay, was sent to prison. James' single mother sister, the drugged out Krista Coughlin, and Doug have a casual sexual relationship. The foursome carry out a mostly successful bank robbery, but due to circumstances take the bank manager, Claire Keesey, hostage for a short period before releasing her physically unharmed. They find out that Claire lives in Charlestown, so they want to ensure that she did not see anything that could incriminate them if they were to ever run into her. As such, Doug begins a personal relationship with her to find out what she knows and what she's told the police and the FBI, who have taken charge of the investigation. He learns that she has kept some information from the authorities for her own protection but information that could identify James in particular. But Doug slowly falls for her, as she does for him. Ultimately, Doug dreams about leaving his Charlestown life to be with Claire anywhere but there. But Doug has to try and keep his true identity from her, and keep the fact that he is seeing her from his colleagues. But leaving is not as easy as he would like as he and the gang are tasked with a big job by a local gangster named Fergie whether Doug likes it or not. And Adam Frawley, the FBI's lead investigator, comes into evidence that links the foursome to the bank robbery and a subsequent armored car heist, so is on their tail for evidence that will send them away dead or alive.
